column6: Beta player of £è£á£ã£ë£í£õ£ä since 3rd of July 2016 under the username  UltraHacker25  or  XtremePrime    Single/Multi player The game features two parts. The vLAN and the M.U.D. The vLAN is where you start

column10: but the story is alright and sure to keep you plugged it!  Once you're out of the vLAN
column11: you migrate into the M.U.D. (Multi User Domain) which is the multiplayer and main focus of the game! Here you are allowed to do whatever you want! From figuring out puzzles in order to attack NPCs and steal their GC
column12: to writing scripts using Javascript and running them ingame
column14: to simply just chatting around with strangers
column15: future allies/enemies!   Mechanics Most of the game's core mechanic regarding breaching relies on the player figuring out puzzles in order to unlock the NPC/Player locs to breach their system.  The scripts you have equipped determine what your class is. Currently there are 4 main classes in the game: Infiltrator (Show player access logs
column19: upgrades etc); Architect (More characters per script
column21: more public script slots) and Executive (unsure yet
column22: but it's related to the corporations/clans you can make)  Scripting knowledge is not required in order to enjoy Hackmud
column23: but it sure does help to know some. With time and some help from the players
column24: it will become increasingly easier for you to start writing your own scripts and build future tools for the community to use!    Traits + Great and fitting soundtrack + Friendly community + Freedom to play the game in your style + Lovely UI (if you enjoy terminal-like UIs that is!) + Cooperative gameplay and PvP is a possibility + Neat blend of tutorial and singleplayer experience ? A lot of the game happens server-side

Absolutely

column6: Honestly I wasn¡¯t sure what to expect from this atmospheric horror game so with an open mind I went into the story on an empty stomach and some coffee besides me. A regular monday morning?!   ?	Presentation   The game has this horror flick style going on. The recording look from those old movies with the moving lines and the recording icon in the corner. It gives a creepy feeling
column7: which is good for a horror game I guess
column8: but it got annoying after a bit. But that might be just me. Another thing that stood out is the eerie music. At best clich¨¦ sounding
column9: specially if you¡¯ve seen a bunch of horror movies or played such games. But none the less it is very effective with  the combination of the recordings and special effect sounds. This game gave me a few scares and partial due to the sound.    For the first game of HUSH Interactive combined with Forever Entertainment S..A. it has a lovely female voice actor talking along the way of your journey. The lines are another thing. It started good even chuckled at one point
column10: but she kept going on. The other voice acting was also decent.   ?	Interface/Controls   The controls are pretty straight forward and  you get reminded enough which button to press. I do like the controller and keyboard option. Some games feel better with keyboard controls and other games just beg for that XBOX controller
column12: so it is always nice to be able to choice. Sadly the keybings are not changeable
column13: so those with anotherr keyboard setting then QWERTY I would recommend using the controler.   ?	Plot   You begin playing as a woman fresh from school and hoping to pass an interview in a mysterious hospital. She is filming it on her smart phone while talking and talking. Then she uses the phone as a flashlight (or more likely another phone as it is in sight of  the recording). So chapter (or take 1) revolves around finding a living and breathing human who¡¯ll take that interview
column14: while avoiding a screaming ghost.  Flashback
column16: is from the view of some dude. Or better said his camera. Same thing of finding notes and avoiding a ghost to end with a cut-scene in which he encounters for the first time that ghost thing.   After this is a short chapter and euhm.. rather easy and uneventful. The fast chapter I done in a game
column17: I think.  The final chapter or take
column18: oke I¡¯ll admit that is a good one
column19: is the same with finding notes and so on to reveal a good plot. Not going to spoil it
column20: but it  is good! It was surprisingly good actually.   ?	Replayability   Don¡¯t think I personally will replay the game
column21: but I can imagine that short horror game fanatics will like to.   ?	Conclusion   A short but good horror experience for a sensible price. Looking forward to see more of this combo.

column6: At first glance I thought this game was "  just another Terraria clone "

column9: REALLY enjoyed it. While it does have similar mechanics and visuals as Terraria
column10: the developers of Planet Centauri put in a lot more thought in RPG systems
column11: such as crafting custom spells and being able to train and transform into (so far) every enemy in the game.  Yes
column12: that includes those sand worms that dig through terrain
column13: and it's as amazing as it sounds.  There are even " shiny"  rare variants (different colors and I believe better stats) that you can capture and train or upgrade your transformations into. That part of the game kind of feels like a real time version of Pok¨¦mon with the ability to transform into them.  There's also a farming/cooking system that gives your character permanent stat ups upon consuming something for the first time. I found it to be optional in order to progress in the game
column14: but it's there and can be significant if you enjoy that kind of activity.  Inventory space seems to be absurdly big (still not full after 8+ hours) which seemed weird at first
column16: i honestly really welcomed it.  I find that having to constantly decide which item in your inventory is the least valuable and dropping it in favor for something " better"  is not fun or interesting at all and merely makes exploring and looting more of a chore than anything
column17: and  thankfully you won't have to bother with that in this game.   Playing this in multiplayer (it says beta multiplayer to be fair) as a host
column19: while my friend had to restart the game once or twice when it started to lag for him after being tabbed out for longer periods for time.  In it's current state I would estimate the game to have *at least* 20+ hours content of non-repetitive gameplay (as in seeing new content every now and then instead of straight grinding for resources)

column6: I 100% completed Tomb Raider (2013) today. I'm pretty torn about the game
column7: because there's a great deal of things I liked a lot
column8: and a great deal of things I really hated simultaneously. That's a pretty unusual reaction for me with a game.  Things I liked a lot: - Game feel: Movement feels great
column9: shooting enemies with the bow is incredibly satisfying
column10: jumping and climbing is really smooth
column11: the sort of half-sticky half-cover system is really flexible and felt excellent. I can't stress enough how great it is just running around in the game. This has some of the best auto-platforming I've ever played in a game. - Visuals: The game is really
column12: really gorgeous. Weather effects are great. Environments are mostly excellent and there's quite a bit of variety given that it takes place on a single island. Lara's model keeps changing throughout the game as she suffers more and more abuse--and they very creatively have plot reasons to clean her up every once in a while only to make her bloody and dirty again. - Enemy AI: I generally liked the enemy AI. There are only a few regular enemy types
column13: but they combine them interestingly. I generally felt like I had to move around a bit to avoid getting pincered or my cover shot out or blown up. It felt frenetic and engaging generally. - Bar filling: This game is more stuffed full of bars to fill than any game series other than Assassin's Creed. You are collecting scrap. You are collecting experience. You're using experience to upgrade skills and scrap to upgrade weapons. You're collecting weapon parts. You're collecting GPS pickups and relics (like in Uncharted
column14: they have a little 3D Model) + most relics have a hidden thing for you to find if you rotate the model. Every area has something to shoot or burn or find as a per-level sort of thing. There are like 999 combat bonuses for extra experience. For a mostly fairly linear kind of action-shooter
column15: I felt constantly stimulated with tons of stuff to do. - Ziplines: I don't think people in the real world use ziplines but I love them in video games. - The Puzzle Tombs: The game has optional tomb areas which are basically little mini-puzzle areas. This is good because the main game doesn't have many puzzles. These work great
column16: they're very unique and interesting. Totally totally enjoyed these
column17: wish the game had three times as many. - Tension and Release: The game does a great job alternating between high excitement and low excitement periods. - Long
column18: substantial: This is a 15+ hour game easily. I took 19 to 100%
column19: but that's including maybe 3 hours of replay because of lost save progress.  Things I didn't like: - Game feel: All of the guns sucked in comparison to the bow
column20: the grenade launcher is incredibly weak. - " Big"  enemies: Every single shooting game that features a 10 foot tall enemy that wears tons of armour and takes 999999 bullets and then you have to QTE to kill it and the enemy has lines like " YOUR PUNY WEAPONS WON'T HURT ME"  is stupid. There are no 10 foot tall human beings. This is not enjoyable. No one likes this. Tomb Raider has this multiple times
column21: including two separate boss fights. - End-game combat: About three quarters of the way through the game
column22: all the enemies start having armour and machine guns and combat takes a nosedive. It's much more frustrating without being more skillful. Bullet sponge crap. The last boss fight is like four QTEs. - Setpieces: The game has an enormous number of setpieces where you're in a collapsing building
column27: falling large distances and hitting the ground
column28: etc. These suck. They suck in every game that does them. It's not good gameplay
column29: because it's basically an extended low-control QTE. But the worst part is that after the first time
column30: the spectacle wears off. It's just boring and blas¨¦. You see a bridge and you say 'gee whiz
column31: I wonder if the bridge will collapse as I'm walking on it"  and then it does.  Things I hated: - The intro: The single worst part of the game is the introduction section. How the hell does this happen in so many games? It has forced slow-walking. - Lara getting the crap kicked out of her: Lara gets shot
column38: etc. If you lose a QTE
column39: you are going to get brutally dismembered by an enemy or environmental obstacle. The Conan Clueless Gamer review that emphasizes this is right to. The sounds here are really disgusting too. This is the definition of pornographic. The scenes aren't done to provoke any response other than titillation. It's just stupid. - Genocide: Lara kills maybe 1000-1200 people during the run of the game. Lara kills more people than Kane and Lynch did combined. This is ridiculous. You can't have a moment in the introduction where the game is like " omg big emotional moment lara has to use violence to defend herself killing people is such a big moral responsibility"  and then have her headshot 15 people in a row five minutes later. Either learn to make games with less combat
column40: or stop trying to make it a major plot/character theme. Oh and by the way
column41: the first time you kill someone it's in the context of a group of people burning down a village and killing dozens of innocent civilians and trying to kill you after groping you--there is absolutely
column42: positively no shade of grey here. There's no moral dilemma. - The characters
column43: the writing: The characters are awful. You have a team full of awful sidekicks. There's " Grumpy Old Crazy Man"
column47: " Socially Awkward Nerd"  (this guy actually wears a t-shirt with an Esc key
column49: " Oily Used Car Salesman Jerkoff Who Is Obviously Being Set Up For a Heel Turn Later"
column50: " Sassy Black Woman" . It's pitiful. They're all terrible. The only character who gets any writing behind him at all is the father figure guy
column51: who keeps telling Lara he believes in her
column53: etc etc etc. Which is why it's obvious that he's going to die
column54: but not before he gets to have a dying breath monologue where he tells Lara to be strong. It's all so flat and telegraphed. It's so phoned in. And half the dialogue is cliche stuff. Even the ambient enemy dialogue sucks--the last enemy in the game fired a random audio cue where he said " Hey guys
column55: she's got a gun!"  No duh moron
column56: I just laid waste to an entire civilization. I was really tempted to skip most of the cutscenes. - The story: Hey

column58: it's here and it's just as stupid here.  That's a lot of words to say I'd play another one. It's a big dumb mega-budget AAA game. I think in a lot of ways it's one of the better examples of what it's trying to do this generation. Fire the writer for the next one.

ESPETACULAR!  Um dos melhores do genero! O jogo alem de ser otimo e totalmente diferenciado. Amo esse estilo de jogo mas esse alem de ser bom te for?a querer ver a historia e ''interagir'' com ela. Era para ser um game simples nesse estilo porem o desenvolvedor colocou varias ''meninas nuas'' e a cada progresso voce pode fazer algumas ''sacanagens'' com elas no final de cada fase. Quanto mais vitorioso
column7: maior sera a recompensa.  Consiga 3 das 4 vitorias da fase e fa?a um numero pequeno de ''sacanagens'' com a menina que esta duelando no modo historia. Consiga 4 das 4 vitorias e se diverta em fazer quantas vezes quiser de sacanagens em um modo livre ''na fase''. O jogo e somente para maiores de 18 anos.  Entao nao leia abaixo se e menor ok ? rs.. column10: apertar e outras op?oes no final de cada faze voce poder¨¢ fazer 3 op?oes com a bela mo?a dona da fase amarrada. Seja um demonio ou uma humana voce ira se divertir com as op?oes entre os gemidos de cada uma delas. Finalmente. Depois de 12horas completei o game.  Sei que foi demorado mas valew demais..   P¨®s - Diversao - Graficos - Anima?oes - Trilha Sonora - Historia - Recompensa em cada progresso - Completando o game ira desbloquear uma op?ao de jogo mega interessante e dificil.  Contras - Caso voce jogue lembrar¨¢ desse ponto fraco (um maldito coelho). - Nivel de dificuldade. - Pack lixo e nao vi nada legal. Nao compensa comprar.  - O jogo possui planos de fundo mas sao horriveis. Desenvolvedor foi muito burro.   Resumo. Compre e se divirta se curte esse estilo de jogo. Valew cada centavo gasto. Nao e atoa que o nivel de recomenda?oes na steam esta absurdamente alto.  COMPRE SEM MEDO!  Duvidas? Sugestoes? Criticas? Postem ae!!

column6: Halo: Spartan Assault Spartan Assault is a great spin-off game to the Halo series and should probably for  best result  be played with a  xbox-360/One controller . It has nice graphics although nothing too special and weapons and armor abilities are familiar to the series which have been nicely integrated with the story set around the origin of the " Spec Ops Program"  in " Halo 4" .  It is best described as a from above " twin stick"  shooter game. Taking around 5 hours to play through the 30 mission campaign and around 7+ hours to grind side missions and complete the achievements.  Note that some of the " Spec Ops Missions"  of maps can have absolutely  horrible grinding  missions which requires you to replay the mission several times... For me this and the lack of showing these missions when you start the mission or pause the game
column7: forcing you to get to the menu and take like a picture of them or something in the Spec Ops section of the menu to keep track of it all.   To Conclude    Halo spin-off game    From above " twin stick"  shooter    30 missions    3 side-mission for each mission (total 90 side-missions)    25 achievements    ~12 hours to 100 %    Well integrated weapons and armor abilities true to the series    -No good way to view Spec Ops missions    -Terrible grind for some side-quests shows lack of imagination and could have been a lot better    Halo: Spartan Assualt  is a nice and cheap game which can be quite enjoyable and stays true to the Halo series. While it has some flaws it is well worth the price

column6: Juego de RPG/acci¨®n en primera persona (con posibilidad de utilizar 3a) que nos situa en un mundo debastado por las bombas nucleares y la guerra.   Los que lograron salvarse se escondieron en tuneles
column8: y refugios. Nuestro protagonista forma parte del ultimo grupo y por X motivos deber¨¢ salir al exterior del mismo y explorar el mundo persiguiendo un objetivo.  No es un juego de acci¨®n  por acci¨®n. Tienes que elegir que habilidades desarrollar para destacar en combate a cuerpo
column10: dialogo o combate con armas. Este toque de estrategia/rol hace que el personaje crezca y evolucione segun nos convenga.  El mundo es enorme y se recorre a pie no hay veh¨ªculos o animales que te puedan transportar. A su vez el yermo est¨¢ plagado de hostilidad y enemigos deseosos de saquearte o simplemente matarte por supervivencia. column6: Here's finally my review of Hyperrogue
column7: probably my favorite game on Steam! :)  In a nutshell
column8: Hyperrogue can be described as a minimalist tactical roguelike in the hyperbolic plane. So
column13: and no items except for Orbs (basically spells) which are often activated upon pick up. Hyperrogue is turn- and grid-based
column14: and combat rules are simple: Every attack is guaranteed to hit
column15: and is usually deadly - for monsters as well as for the player. As a roguelike
column16: it has permadeath. To avoid accidental player deaths
column17: the game prevents you from performing actions that immediately result in your death
column18: though there's a hardcore mode for the more confident players. Basically
column19: the goal is to collect as much treasure as possible in different game modes
column21: or for a specific type of treasure. In addition
column22: there are some very challenging quests (most of which would be easy in a Euclidean setting)
column23: and a lot of achievements and leaderboard categories.  The game is easy to pick up
column25: and is suitable for anyone from casual players to science nerds or hardcore players. However
column26: be warned that there are no difficulty modes
column28: and you won't be able to unlock certain game modes (chaos mode
column29: Orb of Yendor challenge mode) unless you're very ambitious. Also
column30: you have to be a top player to legally get 100% achievements.  About the more unusual aspect: Hyperrogue is the only elaborate game that I know which features hyperbolic geometry
column31: a type of non-Euclidean geometry! To give a short explanation for this weird kind of geometry
column32: I start with the other (more intuitive) type of non-Euclidean geometry
column33: elliptic geometry: 2-dimensional elliptic geometry is simply the surface of a sphere. So if inhabitants of Earth couldn't move up or down
column34: they'd be living in an elliptic plane. As a grid
column35: we could combine regular hexagons and pentagons in a way that 2 hexagons and 1 pentagon meet in a vertex
column36: which gives us a " football" . Euclidean geometry is the " normal"  geometry we're used to
column37: and the Euclidean plane is simply a flat surface. For a grid we can use regular hexagons. Now hyperbolic geometry is kind of special: While we can combine regular hexagons and pentagons to get a (positively curved) plane
column38: a possible grid for hyperbolic geometry consists of regular hexagons and heptagons
column39: making it " negatively curved" . If we try to do that in the Euclidean world we are living in
column40: we get a wrinkled surface resembling the structure of corals
column41: and it gets more extreme the larger the structure becomes
column42: to the point where our Euclidean universe can't handle the non-Euclidean madness. However
column43: Hyperrogue uses another method of representation (see Poincar¨¦ disk model)
column44: the same which you see in M. C. Escher's  Circle Limit  patterns: In this kind of representation
column45: cells appear smaller the further away they are from the center
column46: and quickly become too small to display on the screen. But if we travel to those cells
column47: we'll see they're the same size as other cells. :)  An interesting property of hyperbolic geometry is that space extends more quickly
column48: and you could fit the surface area of Earth in a circle with a comparably small radius. As a consequence
column50: and then walking back in the approximately (but not exactly) same direction will likely cause you to end up in an entirely different place
column51: so it's very easy to get lost! Another consequence is that escaping pursuers is easier: Head towards a seemingly small gap between two pursuers
column52: and that gap will turn out to be larger than expected! Also
column53: there is no exact equivalent to " parallels"  in a Euclidean geometry
column54: and if your pursuers try to walk in parallel
column55: the outer ones have to travel a larger distance
column57: conveniently lining up for you to defeat them one-by-one. On the other hand
column58: running into unexplored territory means a lot of cells are quickly revealed
column59: potentially containing lots of monsters.  Another interesting aspect is that you can have a hub land with quick access to many infinitely large lands without using teleporters
column60: or a waypoint system. :) The world of Hyperrogue consists of such hub lands
column61: and lots of other different lands with their own kind of treasure. Each land has some unique mechanics
column63: often requiring an entirely different approach. For example
column64: the starting land - Icy land - has heat-based mechanics
column65: there's a land where the ground vanishes beneath your feet
column66: and there's another (cellular automaton-based) land where the walls have a life of their own
column67: and you have to be careful not to get trapped.  The game is being actively developed
column68: and new lands and game modes are released with major updates: Currently
column69: there are 37 regular and 4 hub lands
column70: which is a lot more than the first Steam release had! Also
column72: and there's probably always a friendly person who will help you if you are stuck
column74: or just want to discuss several aspects of the game. Also
column75: the developer has been very open to suggestions
column76: and is eager to fix reported bugs
column77: and keep the leaderboards " clean"  in case there are obvious cheaters. A drawback is that major updates often introduce a considerable number of bugs
column78: but with the excellent bug fix support they usually don't persist long after being reported.  The game currently has the following modes:   The standard mode where you can collect treasure to unlock more lands
column79: and attempt several quests   Collecting a certain amount of treasure unlocks the respective land in the pure tactics mode
column80: where you can try to get highscores in individual lands w/o using items or monsters from other lands   There's a cheat mode that also gives you access to map editor tools
column81: and lets you experiment with hyperbolic patterns.    In the random pattern mode
column82: lands appear with unusual floor/wall patterns. This mode is not well-balanced
column83: but it can lead to some interesting and fun situations   The Euclidean mode features Euclidean versions of the basic lands
column84: which is interesting if you want to find out which impact the unusual geometry has on the game   You can print a sheet to create a warped paper model of a scene from the game
column85: and there's a mode where the game simulates such a paper model (remember what I mentioned about corals
column86: and trying to embed the hyperbolic plane in our Euclidean world?)   The shmup mode removes grid restrictions and is real-time
column87: allowing for local coop with up to 4 players (I didn't try this mode much)   The heptagonal mode allows you to explore the world of Hyperrogue using a different grid that is a bit simpler (only heptagons)
column88: but where the hyperbolic aspect is much stronger   Collecting a lot of treasure unlocks the chaos mode

column6: SINGLE-PLAYER  I've played GTA IV (for the 3rd time) 6 months ago and now I've finally played its successor
column7: 3 years after its release on PC and 5 after consoles. I've seen several people saying they prefer IV and I suppose it's mostly because of the narrative: besides some inconsistencies
column8: Niko continues to be the best protagonist in the series and his story is way more dramatic than Franklin's
column9: Michael's and Trevor's (the same goes for CJ in the original San Andreas title). Still
column10: V is a bigger game (took me over 150 hours to get to the end
column11: against 55 to finish IV _ more 37 hours for its 2 expansions) and has a way greater mission variety.  One thing that bugged me is how easier this new installment is: escaping the police is a cakewalk; health quickly regenerates
column12: so I've never bought armor (something that was indispensable in IV); and not only your car doesn't explode anymore when it rolls over but it magically turns back on its wheels
column13: like it was a turtle with supernatural powers. Another big letdown is the original music
column14: not as memorable as IV's.  Having 3 main characters may have weakened the drama
column15: but I enjoyed changing from one to another
column16: quickly going to different parts of the map and catching them going about their routines. Franklin could have been way more interesting
column17: never rising above the clich¨¦ of being the smarter guy from the hood
column18: the one who knows that being in a gang in his 30s is pathetic but still failing to move on to an honest living (although he tries at the beginning). Michael is interesting
column19: especially because he's so despicable and has a very dysfunctional family
column20: but also doesn¡¯t stray too far from being a parody of Tony Soprano. And Trevor
column21: the mentally ill Canadian white trash
column22: is the star and could have been the sole protagonist
column23: because he¡¯s the one who manages to be more than a stereotype
column24: with an interesting and dramatic backstory; his introductory sequence
column25: involving an old acquaintance from IV
column26: is mind blowing (literally) and what he does to an apartment he inhabits for a while in Vespucci beach is a riot.   Again
column27: the sense of humor is one of the greatest things about a Rockstar game. Particularly on the ¡°internet¡±: you better check your phone after every mission (thank god we don¡¯t have to drive to a cyber caf¨¦ anymore) to follow the news
column31: and you¡¯ll be missing out big time if you ignore them. TV content is also amazing
column32: as the talk radio stations _ the best program is Chakra Attack
column33: with the great comic J.B. Smoove. GTA still is a great satire of the USA.    The tennis minigame disappointed me because it is very simple
column34: but the golf one is great _ in almost every session I had to play it. There are a lot of other activities
column35: including triathlon _ the last of them is so big that it takes over 30 minutes! Hunting is nice
column36: but it's hard to go very far (those damn mountain lions!). And although I liked Chop
column37: I didn't care about walking him out
column38: especially after Franklin moves from his aunt's house.   There are several references to IV and San Andreas (one cool Easter Egg is OG Loc¡¯s gold record on Franklin¡¯s wall)
column39: so I strongly recommend that you play at least these two before enjoying this one.  ONLINE  I¡¯m about rank 18 now
column40: so I¡¯m still far from having experienced all that the online portion of GTA V has to offer. But
column41: differently than Red Dead Redemption¡¯s online mode
column42: this one is very co-op oriented
column43: so you¡¯ll need good friends to really enjoy yourself. I haven¡¯t noticed any hackers or cheaters yet and that was a pleasant surprise
column44: because I read so many horror stories about that. What I usually meet are players that are reckless or not very good during missions; others that kick you out of jobs because you¡¯re still low leveled; a few that think it¡¯s funny to kill you while you¡¯re going about your business¡­ and some cool players too!   The occasional bugs and crashes
column45: the constant phone calls of NPCs that ask me to buy expensive stuff whenever I enter a session and the fact that the weapons I collect ingame disappear after a while (I guess you only keep what you buy) are very bothersome. But the online game can be great if played with a group of friends that ¡°take the fun seriously¡±
column46: although  I don¡¯t think I¡¯ll play this for the same amount of time I spent in single-player. I¡¯ll probably return only when there are good discounts on property and money prizes for logging in.   If you wish to play it
column47: here¡¯s my advice: forget about grinding
column48: just have fun and the money to buy stuff will come naturally.

column6: Road Not Taken is a roguelike puzzle game about surviving life¡¯s surprises . But life is so often content with stagnation and repetition
column7: offering what seems the same grind over and over and over
column8: soon only occasionally taunting with the glimmer of something new. But that¡¯s just the way of things; everything new becomes old
column10: new  just begins to run out. RNT follows a similar cycle; in the beginning
column11: discovering all these new things and how you can change and adapt them to your uses is exciting and intoxicating. But soon enough
column14: the allure of the prospect of new discoveries waiting just behind each locked gate. RTN is profusely entertaining up until you realize this point has come
column16: its unique and challenging formula saves it for a time
column18: both glaring and minute.  RNT plays off its theme of ¡°life¡¯s little mysteries¡± remarkably well in its gameplay. As the town¡¯s new ranger
column19: you¡¯re tasked in each of your years with rescuing the children lost to the woods during each winter¡¯s storm. To deliver them safely
column20: you¡¯ll have to guide each to any of the waiting mothers
column22: using your limited amount of energy in carrying the odds and ends populating each level. The greatest joy had in this game also provides its greatest challenge; the discovering of new items and creatures that can both greatly hinder or assist you in your search. There¡¯s a surprising amount of variety in the number of ways things can interact
column23: with many even able to change into new forms entirely
column24: given the proper combination. You¡¯ll quickly begin filling your travel book with all manner of creatures and their respective ¡°recipes¡±. Eventually
column25: puzzles that seemed impossible in the beginning are soon found to have only been so due to your own ignorance of some combination relevant to the situation.  But here¡¯s the rub
column26: and it¡¯s one that eventually hinders all games of this sort. After a while
column27: it¡¯s very noticeable which pieces the game favors
column28: and which ones have yet to appear more than once
column29: if even that. There¡¯s a handful of items and creatures that are exceptionally common
column30: changing in relation to your years. In my playthroughs
column31: those handfuls have been identical. The aforementioned variety in items and enemies becomes less so when the same few common assets are used ad nauseam
column33: given the inventiveness of some of the lesser used pieces.  In between winters
column34: your time is spent in the town you call home. Here
column35: you can take your hard earned coins
column39: and trade them for townsfolk¡¯s friendship
column40: a la the story of  Rainbow Fish . In return
column41: you may receive helpful recipes for your book
column43: equip-able trinkets. Early earned trinkets¡¯ perks are useful in smaller capacities
column44: but the greater are earned through repeat visits. They
column45: along with the tradeables found in the forest
column46: make up the other half of the Roguelike formula
column47: namely the part that you lose upon death. Make too many mistakes
column48: resulting in zero energy or too few children saved
column49: and all of these are lost. Given the time investment needed to get the better ones
column50: I¡¯ll admit to believing this a bit harsh
column51: especially since death can often be the result of truly unfair elements brought on by the roguelike system
column52: like unavoidable loss of children to enemies or rare
column53: impassible gates due to poor default placement of pieces.  A point of contention for me lies here as well
column54: particularly in the store page¡¯s embellishment of a winding
column56: unique to each journey. The only narrative comes in the townsfolk
column58: personalities and dialogue alike. Even their preferences in tradeables remains identical between playthoughs. The only change is that of color scheme
column59: and which one is most willing to marry you
column60: which becomes readily apparent early on. Despite store page promises of offering the opportunity to lead a unique life each playthrough
column61: the character with obvious affection for you will always yield trinkets and info for fewer tradeables. There¡¯s no reason to invest in anyone else.   Regardless of my issues with it (mostly with the not-so-random level randomization)
column63: and it¡¯s a unique challenge that I¡¯m going to continue playing
column64: if only to try and earn the remaining pages to my travel book. In retrospect
column65: my biggest issues could easily be rectified with a few randomization patches
column67: a future DLC expansion. As it is
column68: the journey slowly loses its luster more than several hours in
column69: but it never loses its shine altogether. The combination of some amusingly humorous travel book entries
column70: a charming art design and some legitimately unsettling sound work help to mask the budding feeling of familiarity on repeat journeys. I think what¡¯s most disappointing is that despite the game¡¯s want to emulate the  unpredictability  of life
column71: it has instead exemplified how easily it can fall into routine and predictability. While the initial few hours and playthrough are wholly the most entertaining
column72: a lackluster attempt at differentiating narrative and the occasional sense of d¨¦j¨¤ vu on later playthroughs only slightly diminish an otherwise fantastic puzzle-rogue.

The Swapper I Saw this game on a sale in the Steam Store and got interested when I watched video and pictures. The ratings were in the end the deciding factor
column7: so let me return the favor.   Gameplay  The Swapper  is at its core a puzzle game which has a " metroidvania"  exploration vibe to it. By solving different puzzles you will progress further and use portals to navigate through the map. The core mechanics of the gameplay is creating clones which you can switch between " Swap"  and even slow down time to make precision swapping possible. Each clone is expendabel and you really never have a true dedicated body. That is of course only half true as when you occupy a body
column8: can die from fall damage etc. You could by this logic try to explain it all by saying that swapping means transferring your concious
column9: allthough that is not the " real"  truth.  There is a set amount of clones that can be there at the same time. They disappear if they die by fall damage or mechanics etc. another way is simply going through the clones with the clone you currently occupy which makes every clone it touches disappear. The tricky part is that while you only " truly"  ocupy one you still jump or move all the clones at the same time. This together with the different mechanics is what makes the puzzles interesting.  I do not think that any of the puzzles were " too difficult" . The hard part about the game is exploration. I had a hard time making myself play this game
column10: so I used a guide. The puzzles I did on my own beacuse that was what was the fun part for me
column11: but the 10 achievements... I would probably have found  one  at best. Given that
column12: I would say that there is fun for both those who like exploration aswell as the " brain-teasing"  puzzles with minor platforming
column13: who do not want to bother with the exploration part. Depending on who you are
column14: decide if a guide is for you or not.    Other parts The setting of the game is facinating! The graphic is clear and nice to look at while the atmosphere of space and the station? is mysterious. The atmosphere together with the graphics
column16: the story and controls all make " The Swapper"  into a unique game through the quality of all parts. The most memorable part would be the story
column17: atmosphere and the  Swapping  of course. I must admit that I need to replay and better study the story as I was tired when I rushed through the game. Especially since the ending peaked my interest a bit.   To Conclude    Puzzlegame    Exploration    Mysterious    Nice gameplay with satisfying mechanics    10 achievments (hard to find)    Can be finished around 5 hours with guide and solving puzzles without help    Great immersive environment    Fantastic atmosphere with stunning graphics    High quality in all aspects    Great story    -Might be unappealing to those who like a more direct approach without to much exploring or navigating where you are.    The Swapper  is a very well made game which shines with its unique vibe of high quality and ingenuity. For me the exploration was a bit of a hinder but could still be a very enjoyable experience by having a guide " holding my hand"  throughout the game. As said before the achievement (secrets) are very well hidden and none of the puzzles felt too hard. You might get stuck sometimes but in the end it is not that complicated and gives you a good " brain-tease" . I bought it at a sale for  2
column18: 65¢ã  which was well worth it. I have no idea how long this game will take to fully complete without a guide
column19: so I will not say that it is a too short game. I will say however that I can really  recommend it  if you like me
column20: like puzzles with some engaging gameplay. It might be well worth it at full price for those in it for the story and the exploration in my opinion.    //ECE//

column6: Super Sanctum TD I got this at a sale for 0
column7: 99¢ã or something which was well worth my money.  The game can easily be 100% done in less than 15 hours if you know what you are doing and are not unlucky with the " golden idol"  achievement.  What made me interested of this game in the beginning was that it was a Sanctum spin-off. I had just finished Sanctum 2 (only 4p left) and found this when looking through other things by the publisher. To start off a lot of enemies are familiar although there is an excess of them with reskins and stats changes. The retro inspired graphics is decent and the further you progress the more towers and perks you can have and chose from. Perks are important as you from the start have to pay for every tower base
column8: while with some perks you get it for free which can help a lot.  Another very important thing which is very true to Sanctum 2 aswell is that you have an important part to play yourself. On most stages towers will not be enough on their own and you will have to incorporate the use of skills to win. Skills are like towers unlocked the further you progress.  At the start of the game it might quickly feel a bit difficult as you lack a lot of good things. You only have one skill
column9: but can with time unlock so that you can chose up to 4 skills every stage at the same time
column10: the same goes for towers. Perks are from what I recalled unlocked one extra point per new level you complete (14points in total?)
column11: which means that you will not be able to use all perks as you never will aford to invest in all perks at the same time (can be reset anytime).  Ironically there are still skills I have not unlocked despite progressing through the campaign more than 2 times and playing survival.  So as you can understand everything becomes a lot easier when you can use 4 different skills and towers at the same time and have the maximum amount of perks in use. If there is a stage with flying enemies do not forget to bring the anti-air tower...  Difficulty wise I have no clue what some people say. There are a lot of viable strategies and I never had to find a guide or get advice on strats to beat a level. Once I finished the campaign with 3 stars on normal I played it through on hard and only swapped one tower " anti-air"  when the stage had flying and beat the game with ease from the strat I had perfected.   To Conclude    Retro styled TD game    Sanctum series spin-off    Familiar enemies    Perk system    Unlockable skills    Unlockable towers    4 slots maximum for towers and skills to be used at the same time    15 levels each with endless mode for competitive leaderboard    Easy to learn    Many viable strats    Essential to combine good use of towers and skills    -RNG achievement " golden idol"     -Maze building is simple and mostly just placing the tower bases with no requirement to think at all    -Enemies are mostly just reskins    -Lackluster soundtrack    -Does lack something that truly sets it apart from other TDs    Super Sanctum TD  is a TD game with some nice elements
column12: but lacks enough difference to other TD games to make it special. I would give it a 7/10 and recommend getting it on a sale. It is perfect for achievement hunting and some casual TD
column13: with nothing too difficult and few negatives. I also like that it has used many of the enemies and towers from the Sanctum series and replaced the FPS factor with skill usage to incorporate that towers alone will not be enough.    //ECE//

column12: but succeed only in slowing its advance. To break the deadlock

column16: sadness ... are very well managed with varying degrees of difficulty. Hexcells Plus The successor of " Hexcells"  delivers an improved and more challenging version of the original. As the " Plus"  in the name might suggest this game is bigger with 36 levels in total. Like before there are 6 achivements 5 awarded for each world unlocked and the last for completing the game without mistakes.   For more about the gameplay check my review of " Hexcells" . A new memorable concept is added to this game where blues can have a number inside them. by clicking on them they will mark an area and in that area there are the same amount of blues as in the inside of the blue tile with the number excluding itself as a blue. The area can be tuned off and on for better visability and can be marked as finished with right-click(unclickable). Apart from that it is basically the same as its predecessor but more challenging.  I have no idea about the time estimate for completion as I practically did it in one go and took breakes with the game on. 15 hours are recorded so about half or slightly above might be accurate. As I always say when doing these reviews; you should  never  have to  guess  to complete a level
column7: that ruins the game and robs you of the satisfaction of completing it legit.   To Conclude    36 levels    6 achievements    Completion est. 7-10 hours?    Enhanced version of Hexcells    Casual    Good difficulty   -Some levels are huge and a misclick is horrible...     Hexcells Plus  is an improvement to " Hexcells"  and was very enjoyable to play after finishing Hexcells. It also provided something that the predecessor could not; difficulty. While it varied it felt like the levels in general were more difficult and the " gloves or hand holding"  was not as much as in previous installation. In fact level 35 was so difficult that I had to get help
column8: it was in a league of its own. Thankfully one pointer and I could slowly progress and get stuck for short amounts of time untill I finally solved it! As " Hexcells infinite"  has a level generator it might seem better
column9: but those levels are not as interesting or nearly as well made and you almost pay twice for it. In my opinion Hexcells Plus gives the best quality vs value of these 3 games.  Probably I would go for Hexcells Plus if I were to choose one of these three games. I recommend it over Hexcells and in general. 2.99 ¢ã feels a lot more reasonable in this case but I still would recommend getting it bundled or at a sale. If you want to support the Dev  Matthew Brown  consider buying it at full price it is not a bad deal.   //ECE//

column6: Lavado de cara visual y sonoro a un clasico de Sega Master System de principios de los 90.   El juego mantiene la misma estructura y dise?o de nieveles que el original
column8: la unica mejora implementada es el exquisito redise?o grafico que nos permitir¨¢ alternar en todo momento entre  actual (dibujos y animaciones hecha a mano) o el tradiciona (pixel graphics de 8 bits)  La banda sonora comparte el mismo sistema pudiendo alternar entre  grabacion instrumental o la clasica m¨²sica de 8 bits  Recomiendo este juego a los que lo disfrutaron en su d¨ªa y quieran repetir ese momento de nostalgia incluyendo el sistema de logros.  Para el resto de usuarios
column9: brevemente os introducir¨¦ que el juego es  scroll lateral  de corte cl¨¢sico mezclando acci¨®n con toques metroid ya que necesitaremos mejoras para avanzar en ciertos puntos.   La duracion puede oscilar las 4-5h y el nivel de rejugabilidad es algo excaso aunque se implementa un nuevo modo en el cual la vida disminuye.  Conclusi¨®n== El juego es una llamada a la nostalgia que satisfacer¨¢ a los puristas que solo quieran tener el juego y disfruten de la nueva animacion pero dejar¨¢ con ganas de algo m¨¢s de sustancia a los jugadores experimentales en el genero que busquen acci¨®n.  Hay que recordar que se trata de una Adaptaci¨®n gr¨¢fico-sonora de un clasico de los 90 y si solo evaluamos eso tenemos un juego notable. Si se tratara de un Remake al uso lo evaluar¨ªa de un modo m¨¢s severo.   Esperad a una buena rebaja y no dudeis comprarlo pues en cualquier caso es divertido.  Nota final 8/10

column6: I bought this game for less than 2¢ã. Turned out it was the smartest investment I've ever made. A brilliant and unique game with strong emphasis on the story rather than constant action and shooting. This game requires to be played patiently and thoroughly since there are a lot of hidden passages and areas. Also
column7: each mission can be approached differently so the game deifinitely has a replay value. Graphics are a bit outdated
column8: but it's not really a problem when you're playing an immersive and clever game like this one. Long story short
column9: this game is a masterpiece. My highest recommendations.

column6: Toybox Turbos This game feels really unique. In fact I have not had such a positive surprise like this one for quite some time!  It is a racing game with six different game modes (only one in mp) which incorporates a very nice concept; Cars with guns and powerups. There are older games and mario kart alike games that remind of this game. They share a very important success factor; they are great party games which gives replayability.  The setting is beautiful with great immersion to the condcept of the toy vehicles you race with. The camera of this  top-down  viewed game is really good single-player but can be frustrating with other players as it becomes difficult to see if you are far ahead which means that you have to know the map to effectively outrun other players without the risk of dying.  There are a couple of power ups available in this game: mines
column11: and EMP (I think it represents). The hammer is ridiculously un-balanced as one hit instant-kills a pleyer and you have 4... This is particulary obvious on a certain single-player track... The mini-gun is very powerful but not as insane as the hammer. The game features 16 achievements which are very well made and is the reason I eventually bought it. It is a good amount not too few or too many. Another thing that has to be mentioned are that there are some small bugs (fell through a stage twice and died by jumping too high on a ramp) and that some people have resolution or startup issues. Me and my brother only had a game crash each.  There is one game in particular that I have played a lot which is similar and the first game I think of:  https://store.steampowered.com/app/281280/Mashed/   ||||| " Mashed"   has better balanced weapons and is more focused on weapons. The stages and graphics are not as good and the vehicle variety is very small. I think that the pricetag 4
column12: 99¢ã that Mashed has should be the same for Toybox Turbos as 14
column13: 99¢ã is waay to much to ask for. If you like Mashed check this game out the same goes the other way around. |||||   Single Player Toybox Turbos has a " single-player campaign"  where you can clear bosses to unlock them as playable cars*(not all can be called cars) for multiplayer. I was very satisfied playing the campaign as it was well balanced between difficulty and challenge past the first cup which was too easy.  Basically there are a couple of cups which make up the campaign. You can progress to the next one after earning a certain amount of stars (unsure if boss has to be beaten to progress). A maximum of three can be awarded per stage depending on your performance.  Each cup has a couple of stages with different game modes and a boss. All cups have a certain type of vehicles tied to the area (service cars
column15: racers etc.) which means that you have to buy at least one new car at each cup to be able to pay. Money is awarded based on performance for each stage
column16: but there are also (usually) coins on the stages that can be collected to make a little extra. Coins are only used for buying cars.  It took me about 3 hours to beat the single-player campaign and get every achievement. While some stages can be hard and  VERY  unfair
column17: it is not a long game though with its 35 vehicles and 18 courses it has some good content.   Multiplayer Multiplayer can be played both locally and online with up to 4 players. A complaint made by others which is very true is the lack of players online. If you intend to get this game make sure to have friends to play it with as that is a big part of this game
column18: online or local does not matter except for  achievement . You can set bots and change some settings
column19: most notable is the " artillery"  option (think it was called artillery). It gives knocked out human players the ability to lock on and hit players with a rocket. This can be done several time as it has a cool down intead of a limit of one.  I have almost played multiplayer as much as single-player and believe that it is the most fun part about the game. It is the only replay value to me and can be very fun especially with " buggy"  things happening or stage hazards. I like to use heavy vehicles and bully light vehicles. It is one of the best things about this game that you can drift and shove other players out the stages etc.    To Conclude    Top-down racing game with powerups    Single-Player Campaign    Beautiful graphic with immersive " toy courses"     35 vehicles    18 courses    16 achievements    Unlockable boss vehicles for Multiplayer    Coin system to unlock cars for the campaign    Star-rated performance for each of the stages    7 Cups with specific vehicle types available to each one    6 game modes (campaign only]    Shortcuts    4 player online/local which can be mixed together    -bugs (can be fun too :D)    - Some experience startup or resolution problems    - Short: only 3 hours~ to finish campaign and all achievements    - 0 players online    - Overpriced   Toybox Turbos  is a very fun game with lots of replayability if you have some friends that play the game online or come over to your couch. It is a party game with and enjoyable campaign
column20: but sadly waay to pricey vs the lenght. I recommend this game if you can get it during a  sale  and have  someone to play it with regulary . When I got this game me and my brother played it for almost 6 hours in one session with half of it together in the middle of the night. I hope the price gets down to 4
column21: 99¢ã retail as the asking price is again waay to much! I am very happy with this game but I payed a very small amount for it.   //ECE//

column9: both because of its story and its smooth gameplay. You really feel like you are some kind of future ninja badazz cyborborg slashing everything in your way with this game. You have an energy bar called ¡°blade mode¡± that allows you to slice apart almost everything in the game

Echo Tokyo: Intro  Summary: Echo Tokyo: Intro is a mini-game that acts as an introduction to the Echo Tokyo world and its people.  Included within are short interactive graphic novels telling origin stories of some of the main characters of the city.  Currently the game includes the following stories:  Shizume's Origin Story - Which includes full voice acting and narration. Coming within the next few weeks is a second story that will introduce Keiji to you all
column7: a powerful mercenary within the game. Echo Tokyo is the last bastion of humanity.  A nuclear fog has made street level uninhabitable.  Now hundreds of years later Echo Tokyo lives on
column8: by building bridges and platforms between the skyscrapers to create a new city in the sky.  This cyber punk city somehow manages to function without government or law
column9: where the companies rule and order is what people make it for themselves.The first short graphic novel story introduces Shizume Misaki
column10: in this fully voiced graphic novel telling her tale as she begins working as a Fixer within Echo Tokyo.  It is said that a fixer will take any job as long as the price is right. Though many act mainly as private investigators
column11: many others will do any job to pay the rent.  What will become of Shizume on one of her first big jobs as she visits into the most dangerous area of the city... The Slums.  This story includes over 6000 words of spoken lines.  As well as 80 unlockable illustrations to the complete the story. The second short graphic novel story introduces Keiji Light and is due to be released within the next four weeks before the end of February.  This fully voiced graphic novel telling his tale
column12: from when he was abducted and experimented on as a child and what that means for him now.  This story will include over 6000 words of spoken lines.  As well as around 80 additional illustration to unlock.  My opinion : Echo Tokyo: Intro and a super cool game the graphics are really nice game and well done as the music used at the right time the scene is of good quality and more in the game and so I think Kickstarter campaign to make a small game so .the has great potential as future DLC has come that makes me really want then the game really has a style of its own and I really love the choice of action we had to do during the story and a good game of this quality cost 3 euro and recent and bloody + DLC to 99 cents  Th¨¨me :  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kZitX3T_bg0   Conclusion :  this game is worth the cost for the story set to music at the right time and really affordable and the DLC comes out later this month in February (and the next studio project which seems equally interested)

column6: The only regret I have after finishing  Layers of Fear  is that I won't be able to experience the game like the first time I played it
column7: ever again. It was a memorable journey
column10: was worth every cent.  You play as a painter who's gone insane over his obsession with perfection in his works of art. Through the story you'll recall memories that surrounded him and his family and how his profession completely changed his world
column11: his attitude etc. While the narration is not particularly mind-blowing
column12: it's the events which happen throughout player progression that mainly consolidate the story. The game is split in a prologue and six chapters
column13: all of them happening around the spectrum of your  magnum opus
column14: a new masterpiece you're working on. As you are progressing through the narrative you will understand how the plot takes a darker turn with each new chapter.  In regards to the genre
column15: I can firmly say that  Layers of Fear  does a fantastic job at bringing suspense and fright to the player. There is no combat
column16: and dying will not have you reload an older checkpoint (though it will lead to a different ending). Instead
column17: most of the horror is brought to you by the uncertain and the jump scares. Indeed
column18: the game is filled with them
column19: but in my opinion they make the game a lot better. Sure
column20: many people may disagree with me here. I am not a fan of cheap
column22: and that's exactly why I loved them in  Layers of Fear : they're different. It's difficult to explain exactly how they work without spoiling the game. In short
column23: they're much more than random meshes thrown at you. It feels like they're building the story in their own way.  The gameplay is the standard one usually encountered in games of this sort: you walk/run across the rooms
column24: interacting with the environment in order to progress or to uncover memories of the protagonist's past. You can not defend yourself from the enemy
column25: but there's only a few encounters with them
column26: all of which can be avoided as well.  The graphics are absolutely top-notch and a notable feat both from the development team and the Unity engine. Many times I stopped from advancing in the game only to stare at the paintings on the walls
column27: or at the attention to detail in various scenarios. It is definitely a visual gem
column28: which immensely adds to the immersion factor and overall to an even greater atmosphere.  The sound design is purely a masterpiece. Being an audiophile
column29: I paid attention all the time to the background noises and music.   The sound effects are very well polished and in harmony with the pace of the game. The wind and the trees outside
column31: whispers of the past etc. all make up for the horror ambiance.   The voice acting
column33: is not half bad. Most of it will be heard when the player finds a memento
column34: so it's not intrusive in any way.   The soundtrack is astounding and one of the main reasons I replayed the game multiple times. Immersive melodies accompanying the player
column35: with changing themes depending on the scenario.   It is worth saying that  Layers of Fear  is an incredibly atmospheric game
column36: mainly because of the aforementioned graphics and sound quality
column37: but also thanks to the incredible level design set by the developers. It's a game playing with your brain
column38: the rooms changing their appearance as you trigger certain events
column39: returning to some places only to find them completely different etc.
column40: delivering the player a taste of the painter's madness.    Summary:     Pros:   + Unique
column43: amplified by a dark story line
column44: breathtaking visuals and exceptional sound effects; + An atmosphere unseen before
column45: with an interesting level design concept (interiors changing as the player looks back etc.)
column46: living up to its title of " psychological horror" ; + Marvelous soundtrack and totally immersive audio effects; + Gorgeous graphics; + The story is mostly built by the world elements the players can interact with
column47: never enforcing cutscenes; + In my 20 hours of playtime I don't recall encountering a single glitch
column48: let alone game breaking bugs;    Cons:   - No replayability; I
column50: have finished the game multiple times in order to better understand the story (and to get the remaining achievements); - The fact that dying only affects the ending and has no real consequences during gameplay kills a certain amount of the tension;  - While not a big issue
column51: I feel like the game could've been longer

column8: known only by his number: 47. He is a high skilled assassin

column10: who works as 47¡¯s boss and some kind of ¡°mother figure¡± to him.   Gameplay   Most levels in this game work like this: you are set loose into an open world environment with people doing their jobs and thing. Among those people there your targets

column6: Halo: Spartan Strike Like its predecessor " Spartan Assualt"
column7: the game is a from above " twin stick"  shooter spin-off Halo game. As mentioned in that review I recommend playing it with a  Xbox-360/One Controller . The story line is about palying as a Spartan/s
column8: denying the enemies the conquest of Earth. Now you will start to face the Prometheans
column9: the enemies introduced in " Halo 4"  and the graphics and overall game experience has improved with this installment.  There are still 30 missions
column10: but the side-missions (still 3 per level) are now displayed with the start of each mission and if you replay the mission you can even track the progress towards each mission. This is a great improvement and the grind missions are fewer
column11: but still some annoying ones. Overall I also felt that the difficulty was lower in this game eventhough I excpect theme to finish in about the same time. You can also make things easier by buying " perks-per mission" ( do not remember what they are called) increasing damage or score awarded etc. This is really helpful for achieving some of the harder gold medals. The game feels a little more original than " Spartan Assualt"  but still greatly incorporates the weapons and armor-abilities mostly found in the original series.   To Conclude    Halo spin-off game    Better graphics than previous installment    From above " twin stick"  shooter    30 levels    20 achievements    5 hour story     ~12 hours for 100% completion    3 side missions per level for a total of 90    Side-missions can now be viewed when entering a mission
column12: huge improvement over " Spartan Assualt"     -Still some grindy unimaginative side-missions   Halo: Spartan Strike  is an overall improvement to its previous installment " Spartan Assualt"  which still is fun to play and well made. It further expands from and stays true to the Halo series giving a solid time-killer experience. I highly recommend getting the bundle to get both " Halo: Spartan Strike/Assualt"

column36: new student transferring into Mihama Academy
column37: which essentially acts as a super-restrictive private school for people who have lots of issues and
column39: special reasons to be there. In Yuji¡¯s case

column42: Yuji asks to experience a ¡°normal¡± life for a while
column43: and while putting a trained killer into a normal school probably isn¡¯t a great idea
column44: accommodations are made to place him in Mihama
column45: where his personality defects will be less problematic. As the plot progresses
column46: you¡¯re introduced to his five female classmates: Amane
column47: a ¡°horny big sister¡± type who¡¯s repressing a good bit of her childhood
column49: whose kuudere tendencies mask a life she¡¯s not thrilled to be a part of

column53: a fake tsundere whose behavior masks something far more depressing

column59: it¡¯s your job to guide Yuji into the life of one of these ladies
column60: in hopes of helping both the lady in question

column7: I have to admit that I love this kind of casual games. IF you don't like casual or match 3 games
column8: then this one may not be for you. This game was given to me for beta testing
column9: so when the alpha comes out it may slightly be different.  ?	Presentation  This game is rather cute and cheerful considering the story. On the story I'll talk in a bit. First the menu. The background of the menu is a lovely beach (let's forget about the half sunken ship and the weird floating block of tofu). Crashing waves in the background. A bird chilping. It all makes you forget about the tofu infected pizzas and the zombies. Actually this game makes you want to go on a holiday or if you can't afford one just keep playing and match those bright coloured sweets. (Darn I want some sweets now)  Oh and if you click the menu background you get a small sparkle. Bit unneeded
column10: but cute none the less.  ?	Interface/Controls/Features  The controls are pretty straight forward and you get reminded enough what to do (if you keep the tutorial on). Now and then you will get a hint too. Just like most games in this genre you only need a mouse to play. The game sometimes react a bit too fast when it comes to swapping sweets
column11: but that could be more to due to my impatience than the programming itself.  One little feature came as a suprise
column12: but a good one. When you play and you are running low on turns you seem to get a bomb. And who doesn't like a nice BOOM?  Another feature is the difficult level. Like in most games you have 3 kinds. You have the normal setting
column13: the casual one where you get more turns in a level and the relax mode where you get only one star at the end but it has no turns. At the beginning of each level you can change this if needed.  ?	Plot  This is a bit of clich¨¦ as you
column15: strand on a remote island. By chance
column16: that island is literally the last resort of the fleeing masses from the zombies or better said rabid ex tofu lovers. Not totally original but it is filled with funny one liners and light hearted humor. Plus the focus is not so much on the story as on fun on playing the levels
column18: puzzles and over all fun.  ?	Replayability  The levels are replayable and you might often have to do so. To get enough cash to build buildings for your resort or to get 3 stars on a level. The game also has different settings for the difficulty. Always handy if one level proves a bit hard or when your child wants to have a go too.  ?	Achievements  This game of zombilicious one-liners offers a bunch of achievements and some require some creative thinking.  ?	Conclusion  A fun 3 match game for the casual gamers or those who need a break from shooting the brains out of zombies. Just give them an overload of sweets and build that resort! And it offers divercity with the solitair tournament
column22: ..  Maybe a little tip but besides the 3 matching of sweets you also get a solitaire tournament after a while. So how is this useful info? Well let's say you are a bit stuck because you don't get enough cash from the normal levels. After all building is expensive everywhere. Then achievement hunting and the solitaire might get you there in your little paradise away from the mindless zombies.  One little thing that annoyed me after a while was the background sound at the solitaire tournament. Specially the laughter of the woman.

Flowers -Le volume sur printemps-  is a yuri visual novel  developed by Innocent Grey and published on Steam  by JAST USA. However
column7: Flowers stands out on its own. Set in a Victorian-esque school in Japan
column8: it warms your heart to see the characters grow. You see them learn. You see them falter. You see them practice. Most of all
column9: you see them interact. the game truly shines through its music
column11: and story development.    Music:   The music is absolutely amazing. It was very relaxing and had a very chill tone to it. The piano was uplifting at times and
column13: downright depressing. It was very fitting.     Artwork:   It just shines. . Flowers is the type of visual novel that the artwork attracted me first. I had no idea what kind of story this game had other than it was a yuri (Girl x Girl) visual novel. The British-inspired backgrounds really made the game feel like was outside of Japan and the pretty-looking sprites gave my eyes plenty of treats. The CGs also pack a punch.    Story Development:   I may have come for the art
column14: but I definitely stuck around for the story. A brilliant story of how a recluse decides to change herself for the better becomes even better once the element of emotion was added to the story. Flowers is the story of Suoh Shirahane . As a person who rarely attended public school and was home-schooled for most of her life
column15: she is sheltered and  in her own corner of her mind. With the help of the school¡¯s special Amiti¨¦ system (Friendship System)
column16: she tries to change herself to be more outgoing and less of a shut-in. However
column17: that is not as easy as one would think. The story also does not take this lightly and properly explores the reason she is how she is. Not only that
column18: but it also explores the lives of the other characters and their developments through the game. The story definitely left a good impact on me. I also very much enjoyed how the game had an intellectual factor. The ¡°quick-time events¡± where Suoh needed to know certain info in order to progress was actually fun and had me looking up info to things I was culturally oblivious to before. refreshing for a visual novel to expand my knowledge and Flowers certainly did that for me. With all that said
column20: the game does have its flaws. For one
column21: it is absolutely riddled with grammar and editing mistakes. Sometimes
column23: not so obvious. For the most part
column25: the reading was solid.    Pros:      great artwork    Unabashed storytelling    Relaxing Soundtrack    Intellectual engagement     Cons:      Riddled with grammar/spelling errors     Fullscreen can be temperamental    Voices can be unbalanced at times.  I highly recommend Flowers -Le volume sur printemps- very much. It¡¯s intellectually gripping at times
column28: very good read. I had fun with its mysteries
column30: and storytelling. Even with the apparent flaws
column31: the game is actually fun and lovingly crafted.  Also yuri  ( ?¡ã ?? ?¡ã)  This novel gets a solid 8/10 for me

Escape the Past  is a rather short and simple adventure game with basically no story whatsoever. Despite this (I mean having no story in an adventure game is a rather serious issue) the game is something that could be called a relaxing experience for roughly about 2 hours while it lasts.  The game consists of 4 chapters and our goal is to escape or leave a mysterious island
column7: where apparently 'time does not pass and every day is the same'. Unfortunately there aren't any introduction or cutscenes
column8: all we get are letters (what's written in them can symbolize many things depending what we want to envision or see into them) at the end of each chapter
column9: after reaching the exit (which is usually a door of some sort). The puzzles are quite easy and we can only get stuck by not noticing an item that can be used (or by playing the entire 1st chapter through in French
column10: just like I did). The game provides many hints though
column11: usually suggesting what kind of an item we need in order to progress. The user interface is the same as the one commonly used in other point-and-click adventure games: we see our items listed below and by selecting them we can use them on the screen
column12: where we think an interactive object might be. Some of the items can (and must) be combined. In each chapter
column14: we can also collect 5 gems and the 3 pieces of said letter we can read at the end of the chapters.  While the graphics is not something I would call nice
column15: the art style is interesting and it uses warm colours which are pleasing to the eye. I liked the music as it was relaxing
column16: but again it's not something I'd call a masterpiece. There's no voice acting (there is no other creature than us on the island anyway) or any spoken dialogue at all
column17: not even narration. Make sure to set the language to English (or German
column18: or whatever language you speak and is available) in the menu by clicking on the large flag
column19: because originally it is set to French.    Escape the Past  is a simplistic but relaxing little adventure game
column20: which may offer some entertainment despite not really having a story. While 5¢ã may be a bit much for it
column21: at a 75% discount I would recommend it for some short-term casual fun.  PROS + easy puzzles if you like them + enjoyable gameplay + relaxing music  CONS - not much of a story - very short - base price could be lower  RATING 5.5/10

column6: Let me get this straight ahead and confirm that the wait for SOMA was
column8: well-worth it. Frictional delivers yet another masterpiece. I even dare say they followed the saying: ''There's always room for more.''
column9: after their fantastic Amnesia series. What we got from them here is one of those existential questioning games... combine that with horror
column11: incredible  sound effects and you get a memorable gem.  SOMA has less enemy encounters than Amnesia
column12: but I say it's for a good cause. What it lacks in terms of monsters
column13: it completely delivers with the story. I'd say they got the perfect balance between hiding and actual advancing through the events. More encounters would have made me forget about the plot and it would have gotten unimmersive. But when there is a monster showing around
column14: expect it to be a challenging part. No more hiding in a corner and waiting for it to leave as in previous games
column15: as SOMA's creatures are not just randomly going away after a while. They'll stay in your path and you have to carefully progress through the chambers and remember the map
column16: in order to get away safe and sound.  I did mention this is more of an existentional questioning game. I can't dig deeper into details on this one as it would all lead to story-breaking spoilers. Heck
column17: even the premise of it is a spoiler. All I can say is that it successfully made me question what it is to be a human and what distinguishes us from artificial intelligences --robots-- .  What I also loved about it was its length. 13 hours to finish an indie game is nothing short of amazing and I didn't even stay to read all notes and journals. I'll definitely give this game a second playthrough.  The inventory has been massively simplified since Amnesia and the sanity/health system is also changed. Looking at some monsters for too long will give away your position and health can be restored at healing places throughout the journey.  Technically speaking
column18: the game suffers from a poor optimization. I was getting massive frame drops in some places. Visually it does not excel either. But I can get past these issues coming from a small company. On the other side
column19: I haven't encountered many bugs nor grammatical errors and kudos to the developers for taking their time and patching up their game!  *End-game debate incoming (definitely spoilers ahead); please skip to next paragraph for general personal rating if you haven't completed the game yet.* The feeling that was following me up to the very end was one of d¨¦j¨¤ vu. There is another game out there that raised the exact same questioning:   The Talos Principle. Apocalypse
column20: AI that would replace the mankind and would live through a new aeon? These two games are as if set in the same universe. If you put away the gameplay of them
column21: you will notice that they both follow the same plot.  Is artificial intelligence capable of replacing the human brain? In SOMA
column22: a group of scientists work in projecting it on digital chips. The Talos Principle follows a similar path
column23: with one AI already constructed and left in sleep mode until it proves that it acts and  thinks  humanlike. In both games you are playing as a virtual mind placed into a carcass
column24: in order to continue human legacy. Could these two games be set in the same world? The similarities between them are astonishing. Also
column25: SOMA's concept of replicating someone's mind is extremely intriguing. Are you the first AI copy of Simon after his death? Like in the end of the game
column26: where he is duplicated and a part of him remains alone for an eternity on a wasted planet
column27: while the other rests forever in the ARK
column28: on a digital island.. The main character could very well not be the first copy of his brain awoken.      Pros:   + Excellent plot and an overall amazing storyline. The journey that the player takes from the beginning to the end never ceased to amaze me. + Incredible sound effects. Not just one time have I thought some environment sounds are actually coming from my room.  + Perfect mix of horror and story telling. + Impressively long while still maintaining to not get boring. + Great puzzles that add to the core
column29: just like in the Amnesia series. + The atmosphere perfectly blends in. + The voice acting is also well-crafted. + More types of monsters with different behaviors. They also have some great sound effects implemented
column30: you will hear them if they're wandering on a nearby corridor or if they have detected you. + Overall balanced difficulty. Does not make the player replay the same area countless of times due to dying
column31: but is also thought as to not be rushed through with ease. + Does continue Frictional's unique horror style.    Neutral:   +/- Different system of health and sanity
column32: like shortly described above. Some players may welcome the changes with open arms
column33: while others may dislike it compared to the old one from Amnesia: The Dark Descent. +/- Depending on everyone's tastes
column34: I suppose the game suffers from a lack of replayability. +/- Enemy AI. They're not brainless
column35: but nothing amazing about their thinking either.    Cons:   - Poor optimization... may encounter frame drops
column36: stutter and even freezes in some areas
column37: even while lowering the settings. - Infinite battery flashlight. A similar system to the one from older Frictional titles would also suit SOMA better in my opinion and would add to the difficulty. - Uhm... where's the enemy robots? I was disappointed to only encounter the big machines with flashlights 2 or 3 times and only in the first quarter of the game... They were some great enemies in my opinion and would have surely also suited some other areas. - Can get extremely frustrating to cope with the visual screen tearing while the monster is chasing you. Later on in the game
column38: you're almost always getting caught by it if he sees you
column39: anyway.  SOMA is a must for anyone that loved Frictional's other games. For the others
column40: this is a great decision if you're looking for a thrilling story with scary elements and atmosphere. I definitely not regret pre-ordering this one and I want to thank the developers for bringing in another masterpiece to Steam.  Personal rating: 91/100 - Amazing
