Binary Domain was yet another part of a (free) bundle given away by SEGA
column7: featuring mediocre games mainly. When I started playing it
column8: I was expecting an average shooter (the reviews didn't provide much clue). What I got was an absolutely positive surprise in all aspects. But I'm not explaining this fact that I liked this game so much with the element of surprise: I wish every overhyped AAA game could provide as much fun as Binary Domain did. It has everything a good game needs: a thrilling story
column10: choices & consequences and of course great combat with fluid controls. This is one of those games that would require a sequel
column12: since the game never received the proper amount of praise and appreciation it should have deserved.  We are in 2080
column14: Dan Marshall is sent to Tokyo
column15: Japan on a covert operation as a part of an international strike team to investigate the case of a robot manufacturing corporation. This firm is apparently assembling highly advanced human-like robots
column16: which is prohibited worldwide. The case is of course more intricate and dangerous than it first appears to be and soon Dan is going to have to make some tough choices as he makes shocking discoveries not only regarding the plans of the sinister Amada Corporation
column17: but also about some of his own teammates.  The game uses classic
column20: combined with the cover using system similar to the one in Mass Effect. The effective use of covers is mandatory on higher difficulties as the enemies always attack in large groups and use rapid firing machine guns. There are (slidebar-based) quick time events during cinematics
column22: these are are not annoying at all
column23: like in some other games (they are just ensuring we don't fall asleep during the cutscenes
column24: which wouldn't happen anyway). Our enemies are (mostly) humanoid robots and shooting them is termendous fun: they break
column25: explode and fall apart in the most spectecular ways. Their armor plates fall and shatter as we shoot them
column26: their limbs come off but they remain dangerous even after being crippled
column27: they can crawl around and jump on us. Boss fights are spectacular
column28: prepare for multi-phased battles and try to use heavy weaponry or alternative methods laying around. Because of the robots the game may appear to be suitable for children at first glance
column29: later on (in one of the first cinematics actually) however due to the sensitive nature of the content being displayed (and the story)
column30: I would heavily advise against it.  The level design is great: altough linear throughout and the corridors the fights take place in are relatively tight
column31: the illusion of large open areas works pretty well. The creators successfully managed to avoid of the clich¨¦ of futuristic underground areas and sewer crawling (altough we got a fair share of those as well) by providing us some exicting and beautiful environments of future Tokyo
column32: such as a caf¨¦ terrace or a crowded disco and an amazing ride on a monorail.  An interesting feature of the game is a unique voice command system
column33: but I would recommend using the buttons instead (don't forget to recalibrate them
column34: the original layout is a bit weird
column35: it is originally a console game after all). This command system is used to give basic orders and also to reply/answer to our squad members. The games also utilizes a trust system which affects certain parts of the story
column36: to an extent that some of our team members can even betray us. The trust level of our teammates can be increased by giving them the right answers when being asked or during combat
column37: by shooting enemies in the head or bashing them in melee (if we shoot them accidentally or are being rude to them
column38: it'll go down). I have to mention here that the dialogues are well-written and funny
column39: there were parts when I laughed out loud (something that doesn't happen very often). We can select 2 (sometimes more) companions before missions
column40: so if we want to be on good terms with everyone
column41: we should choose each one of them at least a couple of times (plus they all react differently at certain key situations
column42: not to mention that the ending changes accordingly
column43: whether a certain character trusts us enough or doesn't). Their AI is pretty good: they won't get p0wned easily (they CAN die permanently however
column45: but don't expect them to take down a tougher enemy on their own either (they can and will automatically revive us
column46: if we are down). The sexy Chinese sniper and the robot with the French accent are usually the best choice (when they are available) since they are both capable fighters and perform well in most situations.  There are vending machines all over the game
column47: where we can buy ammo and more importantly upgrade our weapon's attributes. Everyone comes with a special weapon which they are proficient with and while a secondary weapon can be equipped
column48: everyone should use their primary/favourite weapon class all times for the sake of efficiency. The guns of our companions can be upgraded as well. The nanomachines are enhancements that increase a certain character's attributes (max health
column50: etc. and most importantly a trust level increasing mod - see the picture below) and for additional background information or plot elements security coms can be collected.   https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=726488680   Some people complained about the graphics
column51: something I had no problems with: I found it satisfactory overall and amazing at certain locations (the upper city for example)
column52: not to mention the monumental action scenes where I was simply blown away by the graphics
column55: and the effective use of blur. The characters and facial animations are pretty well made
column56: even today - at the time of this review. The abundance of greatly choreographed cutscenes almost make us feel like we were watching a (good action) movie.   https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=726484956   The music is one of the best I've heard in a video game so far
column57: it's up there with the OST of the original Unreal
column59: Deus Ex or Far Cry: Blood Dragon. It mostly consists of fast paced techno/rave tracks (the one during the  jet ski ride  is especially awesome) with a pinch of Japanese influence
column60: perfect for an action game. The robots and guns sound great
column62: or when the giant robots roar at us. The voice acting is superb as well
column63: even the different accents and word usage accordingly are well made.  I didn't have the opportunity to try the multiplayer mode out
column64: I hope I'll get to one day.  Binary Domain is an underrated gem
column65: which starts out as a 'regular' sci-fi action game
column66: but turns into much more (both in gameplay and plot)
column68: the choices we have to make
column69: the action-packed cutscenes and the splendid gameplay. Do yourself a favour and don't just let it sit in your library... play it

column71: higly enjoyable gameplay + great setting and some amazing looking locations + good plot with interesting characters and well-written dialogues + plenty of memorable cutscenes make the game more cinematic + superb controls (once you reset them) + robots break apart and explode in various ways + impressive boss fights + excellent soundtrack  CONS - original key layout is trash - the joke ending feels quite lame and unnecessary  RATING 9/10

Free with a surprisingly good story. The game is made in the RenPy visual novel engine
column7: which is rather ambitious since the game's core gameplay does not lend itself well to the engine. It takes place on a grid-based chess system reminiscent of games like Fire Emblem
column8: but with less of an emphasis on physical surroundings and more of a focus on spatial distance between targets. The engine does what it can to render everything well
column9: but often times it feels bloated- like they were almost confining themselves by keeping the game in the RenPy engine. The game's battle system is well thought out but leaves much to be desired in its execution
column10: so I would not recommend playing the game on any difficulty setting higher than " Visual Novel."   The characters are enjoyable act as the lynchpin to the game as a whole. As this is the first chapter
column11: it focuses on each of the characters meeting in various ways and learning how to work with each other for the greater good. The plot is reminiscent of a barebones Mass Effect
column12: but I believe that it does a better job at depicting loss in war than titles like Mass Effect 3 did- high praise for a visual novel. There is a little bit of voiceacting for battles. The voicing is fairly reasonable given the budget of the game

NEKOPARA Vol. 0 :    Summary:  Sekai Project originated in 2007 as a fan translation group translating the visual novel School Days.[1] They later partnered with publisher JAST USA
column7: turning their fan translation into the official English version of the game.[2] Sekai Project began publishing games on Steam in 2014. Their first title was World End Economica episode.01
column8: released in June 2014. Sekai Project has used the crowdfunding platform Kickstarter to fund many of their projects. In November 2014
column9: they launched a Kickstarter campaign to fund an English release of the visual novel Clannad. The campaign exceeded its goal of US$140
column10: 000 and ended up raising over US$500
column12: Sekai Project announced that they would be localizing manga in addition to video games
column13: starting with Gate.[4] Sekai Project has stated that they are interested in localising games into languages other than English in future. The German translator Marcel Weyers
column14: who has already translated a number of visual novels into German
column15: has voiced interest in translating titles by Sekai Project and is supposedly in talks with the company.[5][6] Since Steam does not typically allow adult games to be sold on their platform
column16: [7] Sekai Project releases their adult titles through their partner company Denpasoft. For titles like The Fruit of Grisaia
column17: an all ages version is available on Steam
column18: while the uncut adult version is sold directly through the Denpasoft website.[8 Nekopara is a visual novel series
column19: so the majority of the gameplay consists of the player reading the game's story. Nekopara does not offer choices to the player throughout gameplay
column20: and the player has no influence over the story. The games are fully voiced (except for the protagonist) and use a system called " E-mote"  that allows the in-game characters to be animated
column21: instead of stationary sprites.[2] Nekopara Vol. 0 added a new feature where the player can click on characters in-game
column22: to " pet"  them. column6: Far: Lone Sails is the meditative traveling side-scroller game. The gameplay is based around the movement from the very left screen to the very right
column7: with the help of the strange vessel called Okomotive.  You'll need to solve various logical puzzles on your way
column8: which are based mostly on the special features of your vessel. Like the sails: they are needed to push you forward when the wind is right
column9: but once it will be necessary to spread them against the wind to roll back a bit... All the puzzles and game situations are unique
column10: the only repetitive element of gameplay is about fuelling your Okomotive over and over. And sometimes fixing it on the movement
column11: like it was in FTL: Faster Than Light.  The game is quite short
column12: you'll need 1.5-3 hours to beat it... Yet
column13: only the half of the people played it ever made this way to its end. Why? Well
column14: it is boring. Not by repetitiveness
column15: it's all about that 'Deep Atmosphere"  the game promises. It was not made for everyone around. I'd say
column17: like watching the hard rain through your window some cold and lonely October day. If you like watching the rain... Well
column18: I'd say it's a very good game you should definitely need to try. Maybe you'll even get some catharsis at the end of that journey... Or not.  My mark is 6.5/10. column6: Con mejores graficos que el ya conocido COH este juego agrega nuevas dificultades al campo de batalla como tormentas de nieve
column7: bajas temperaturas y lagos congelados. La jugabilidad es similar a su antecesor considerando que ahora hay mas de tres commandantes a escoger y muchos de estos estan disponibles para comprar. Los rusos tienen una forma diferente de organizaci¨®n y los Alemanes mantienen ese mismo estilo con diferencias de armamento y uso de diferentes tipos de Tanques asi como vehiculos. El juego cuenta con un modo llamado Theater of War que sirve para misiones cooperativas o de un jugador ademas de posibles misiones para descargar y comprar. El modo historia ha sido uno de los mas polemicos ya que se opaca mucho a los Rusos por sus actos haciendo que el Metascore quede dividido. Es resumen es un buen juego que no sustituye al actual COH sino lo hace pareja para mantener ambos juegos en entretenidas batallas Online.

Note: So far I only played 4 of the presumably 7 chapters.    Schatte ¡«The Witch and the Fake Shadow¡«  is by no means a must-play title
column7: and there are a lot better games out there. But I'd say it's alright
column8: it has some interesting and unique mechanics
column9: and I enjoyed it so far
column10: aside from some initial needless frustration.  The story is simple: The Shadow Demon had been sealed away
column12: and now takes control of animate beings. For some reason
column15: is unaffected. As a wielder of shadow magic
column16: she heads out to help survivors
column17: and to stop the contamination.  To use shadow magic
column18: Schatte needs to generate a shadow first. She can do this by positioning her familiar
column19: a bat with a jack o'lantern head that emits light. She can then interact with shadows in several ways to stun a target
column22: control a creature to borrow its abilities
column23: or dive into the shadow of an object to either climb slopes
column24: or to pass unharmed through obstacles.  The game itself is fairly linear
column25: and a level mostly consists of walking from the start point to an unspecified target location
column27: or solving puzzles with different kinds of shadow magic. There are some optional collectible objects in the form of journey entries or other documents
column28: but they are usually easy to find.  Once you have figured out the basic mechanics
column29: most fights so far are rather straightforward: Lock the light source to the enemy
column30: throw a Shadow Knife into its shadow to stun it
column31: then jump once or more on its shadow to cure it. Things become slightly more difficult when confronting multiple enemies at the same time
column32: and there was at least one considerably more difficult boss fight. But since Schatte gains experience / levels
column33: there's no reason to be concerned about a too high difficulty.  The puzzles are usually simple
column34: but it still can take a while or some experimentation to find the solution.   What I didn't like about the game:   There's no options menu
column35: except for the unity dialog at launch
column36: which at least allows to choose a resolution / quality setting
column37: and look up / change the controls.   Many parts of the first levels look very bland. But it gets better later.   Maybe it's just me
column38: but at the beginning I had a hard time understanding some of the basic mechanics. In particular
column39: I didn't understand which terms refer to buttons / keys (e.g.  Shadow Stamp )
column40: and which terms refer to actions associated with those (e.g.  Shadow Bind )
column41: and that I was supposed to tap a certain button / key.   There's only a single save state
column42: and the game automatically saves at certain points. That means if you accidentally select  Start  instead of  Continue  in the main menu
column43: you have to play certain parts of the game again. While there is a Chapter select option
column44: it doesn't allow to select single levels within this chapter
column45: and you cannot return to the main menu once you have entered this sub-menu; so if you select this
column46: you either have to replay the whole chapter
column47: or force-quit the game (I haven't tried this
column48: so do this at your own risk!) Fortunately
column49: character level and collectibles are not reset when replaying a chapter.   You can die at a certain part in the tutorial level  before  the game saves for the first time. This can easily happen if you didn't understand some of the instructions
column50: and when this happens you have to replay the whole tutorial with the not-completely-skippable dialogs.  While those issues can lead to some initial frustration
column51: the game plays fine once you know how to deal with those / are familiar with the basic mechanics.   All in all
column52: I'd recommend the game if...   ...you're looking for a small relaxing indie game with a witch theme
column53: and some unique mechanics   ...you don't mind the lack of sound options
column54: or in-game graphics / control settings   ...you are confident in your ability to navigate menues w/o accidentally selecting options that reset some of your level progress   ...you can handle some potential initial frustration (ymmv
column55: maybe I just didn't pay enough attention)   ...you don't need achievements or trading cards

column8: authentisch und sehr gut synchronisiert (jedenfalls in der deutschen Version). Leider sind dagegen manche der Nebenfiguren zum Teil recht clichehaft und vorhersehbar oder haben seltsame Synchronisationen
column9: was aber dem Spiel und seiner Story keinen gro?en Abbruch tut. Die R?tsel sind durchweg logisch und verlangen keine absurden Kombinationen alla Maniac Mansion
column10: was ich pers?nlich sehr gut finde. Leider sind sie aus diesem Grund auch an manchen Stellen recht einfach und man hat schon zu Begin alle Kombinationen herausgefunden und sucht nur noch die Stelle oder die vorgegebene Kombination in der man sie anwendet.   Alles in allem ein Spiel das man auf jeden Fall jedem empfehlen kann der nicht ausschlie?lich an herausfordernden R?tseln interessiert ist. Ich habe das Spiel im Sale f¨¹r 1 Euro geschossen
column11: also da ist ein gebrachtes Buch auf dem Flohmarkt teurer und das muss man dann auch noch selbst lesen...
